intro: Phoradendron wattii var. productum, commonly known as the Hawaiian mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to the Hawaiian Islands. It belongs to the family Viscaraceae and is characterized by its small, evergreen leaves and white, fleshy flowers. The plant relies on host trees, primarily the *Acacia koa*, for water and nutrients, while photosynthesizing to some extent. Its seeds are dispersed by birds, which consume the fleshy berries. This species plays a unique ecological role in Hawaiian forests, contributing to the biodiversity of the region.
